article.headline: Hereâs a hedge fund strategy that just might work for you
article.body: There are lots of analyses out there about what hedge funds are buying, but strategists at Jefferies Equity Research on Friday published a slightly different spin on that theme. The success of this particular investing trend, they argue, suggests not just that hedge funds are âgetting it right,â but that stock-picking may be back in favor. Steven DeSanctis and Eric Lockenvitz broke out the stocks that hedge funds had swapped from long positions to short â that is, those they think are likely to increase in value versus those that are likely to decline â and vice versa. Itâs not just an academic exercise: âThe stocks that hedge funds were short but moved to a long position over the month have posted the best gain in June at 6.7%, and these names are now up 66% from the low,â the Jefferies team wrote (those calculations are as of June 24.) âStocks that moved from long to short are actually down 2.6% and lagging off of the bottom after being one of the leaders.â The performance data suggests something intriguing: could hedge funds be making the correct calls, finally, after years of underperformance? âThere will be many Haves and Have Nots across the market and hedge funds and long only investors will be able to separate wheat from chaff,â DeSanctis and Lockenvitz write. Itâs worth noting that many market observers donât agree. Famed investing guru Burton Malkiel told MarketWatch earlier this week that âmore and more active managers are beaten by the index. Every year itâs about two-thirds to 70% of active managers get beaten. Those that win in one year arenât the same ones that win the next year. There is no evidence that some years are going to be active years. Thereâs no evidence whatsoever that because of COVID-19 itâs time for active management.â If, however, you'd like to try, the two lists of hedge fund holdings, long to short and short to long, are below.
